THE ILLUSIONIST (PG)

France, 2010 (80 min.)

Director: Sylvain Chomet. Screenplay by Sylvain Chomet and Jacques Tati. With the voices of: Jean-Claude Donda, Eilidh Rankin.


Sylvain Chomet’s follow-up to "The Triplets of Belleville" is a gift to all fans of (cel) animation, Jacques Tati, and the fleeting magic of enchantment. The legendary writer/director Tati ("M. Hulot’s Holiday", "Mon Oncle", "Playtime") wrote the original screenplay, intending to play the role of an aging magician in Scotland who convinces an innocent young runaway that his tricks are real - cranky rabbit and all. Nearly 30 years after Tati’s death, Chomet has transformed the script with subtly beautiful animation that captures Tati’s bittersweet wit. Dedicated to Tati’s daughter Sophie, who gave the script to Chomet, "The Illusionist" poignantly speaks to a child’s discovery of their parents’ inevitable fallibility.
